And the mufied drum rolled on the air,
Warriors with stately steps were there:
On every arm was black Grape bound,
Every carbine was turned to the ground,
Solemn the sound Of their measured tread
As silent and slow they followed the dead
The ridelcss horse was led in the rear,
There were white plumes waving DER The bisr
Helmet and sword were laid on the pail. -
For il was soldiers funeral.
That soldier stood on the battle plain,
Where every step was over the slain.
But tile brand and the ball passed him bv
And he came 10 lis native land to die
Twas hard 10 come 70 that native land,
And not clasp one familiar hand!


Twas hard TO be numbered amid the dead
TIRE they could hear his welcome said
But twas something to see its cliffs once moro
And to lay his bones on his own loved shore.


TO think that the friends ofhis youth might wec,,
On the green grass turf Of the soldiers secp.
The bugcs ceased their willing sound
As the coffin was lowered into the ground:
Avolley was fired blessing said
One moments pallsc-and they left the deadl
saw poor and aged man,


Ills step was feeble, his lip was wan:


He knclt down on the new raised mound.
Ills face was bowed on the cold damp ground,
lie raised his head, his tears were done


The father had prayed DER his only son!

day tn. 9th inst a young lady whilst on a visit
to her SISTER il Charlton row, Manchester, was
Stay ing With her servant when her sister was out.
AMI about seven o'clock in the evening fell A.

long tho street, returned and shut the door, and

and muttcring way, She replied, "Wishing the
ladies good night" She afterwards went into the
cellar, and opened slide window, which she
had not either done herself or seen done before


She rctnrnedup the cellar stairs into the scullc.
ry, took down pair ofbellows that hung IN,
ran up stairs MTG one of the bedrooms, and be.
I gan to blow at an empty CRATE. She then came
i down star5in great hurry, and in going down

bruised the skin oil her heel; She went into the
sculIery, got the dripping pan, put some cups
and saucers &c upon il, and put them oytr tile
4 fire, In short time she took them off again.
4 mutterng, "TAcrc you'll do now" She then
caine lnto the sitting room, took up the poker,

want wrcsted i from her, when she ran into the
mont lobby and fell down, the servant took her

hert iu!ently n = short time she seemed to be
awaAing and was asked, "WhAt have you been
/ doing She answered, as at first, 'Wshing
tie lalics good night" During the whole OF
the time shv had her eyes quite closed and the
servant Srl (who Is youns) was SO alarmed, that
she llarel! not leave her but followed her from
thc iirSt. when the Young lady was thoroughly
awt!ted, shl began 10 be sick, and vomited pro,

Healths.--The origin Of health drinking
took it's rise from the time of the Danes be.
ing in England, when it was common with
them, whilst an Englshman was drinking,
to take that opportunity Of stabbing him.
To guard against this Danish tfeachery, the
English entered into combination TO be
mutual pledges of security 70 each other
whilst drinking. When, therefore, an Eng
lishman at that period drank to his friend,
his tacit language was-"Sir, ! am afraid
that some malicious Dane will stab me or
cut my throat whilst | am drinking beg
the favor of YOU to watch carefully that !
may drink safely


10 which his friend was supposed to an
swer, "Sr, will pledge you aud be your
safety" He then replied, Il am much O.
blged to YOU, sir.-your health. that you
may live till have done drinking, and save
me from his wicked Intentions UAiPsrsal

overheard; alarm was instantly given, the
vessel was stopped, and boat put off in
search of the lost man--but to no purpose.

thisp place. The accident happened at about
two A, M. and about ten, before the detach-

yr There are in and about Havana, 750o

They have beet sent from Spain Tor various

stituton. The first year OF their arrival

fords good place for tomb Its suppos-

But so great is the apprehension OF the GO

send large body of troops from Havana to
Mantanzas, because they were commanded
by Cuban officers.


The troops parade every day, either IN the

quail number; inasmuch as 10 mass, they
are not as stout men as the latter.


AS to the ability of a foreign power TO
take Havana, there is great difference OF
opinion. The troops which occupy It hay
ing been sent away from their own country
against their will. might, in case OF an in

If a foreign power should come, might Gre

natives be considered, it viii appear possl.
ble, that without much expense, either OF

Cabana being commanded by ali eminence

An intelligent French gentleman, lately pass
ing thro Alabama, between Tuscaloosa and
Huntsville, declared that the soil was bet
ter fitted for the cultivation Of the vine, than
most of that which forms the vineyards OF
France. He remarked that the abundance
OF the native grape, with the quality OF the
soil and the nature of the climate, attested
it beyond controversy. 1t is we'll for
France" said he, THAT you have no silks
and no vines"

full articles.headline: THE SOLDIERS FUNERAL.
full articles.article:
And the mufied drum rolled on the air,
Warriors with stately steps were there:
On every arm was black Grape bound,
Every carbine was turned to the ground,
Solemn the sound Of their measured tread
As silent and slow they followed the dead
The ridelcss horse was led in the rear,
There were white plumes waving DER The bisr
Helmet and sword were laid on the pail. -
For il was soldiers funeral.
That soldier stood on the battle plain,
Where every step was over the slain.
But tile brand and the ball passed him bv
And he came 10 lis native land to die
Twas hard 10 come 70 that native land,
And not clasp one familiar hand!


Twas hard TO be numbered amid the dead
TIRE they could hear his welcome said
But twas something to see its cliffs once moro
And to lay his bones on his own loved shore.


TO think that the friends ofhis youth might wec,,
On the green grass turf Of the soldiers secp.
The bugcs ceased their willing sound
As the coffin was lowered into the ground:
Avolley was fired blessing said
One moments pallsc-and they left the deadl
saw poor and aged man,


Ills step was feeble, his lip was wan:


He knclt down on the new raised mound.
Ills face was bowed on the cold damp ground,
lie raised his head, his tears were done


The father had prayed DER his only son!

full articles.article:
Singular c0sc IF SjlsnqDt6thsm.-O Tburs.
day tn. 9th inst a young lady whilst on a visit
to her SISTER il Charlton row, Manchester, was
Stay ing With her servant when her sister was out.
AMI about seven o'clock in the evening fell A.
sleep in a clair before the fire. she had not
slept long before she got up and walked to the
front door, opened it and went some distance a.
long tho street, returned and shut the door, and
kept mutterng something to herself. The ser.
want observing she had her eyes shut, asked her
what She hid been doing; when in very hasty
and muttcring way, She replied, "Wishing the
ladies good night" She afterwards went into the
cellar, and opened slide window, which she
had not either done herself or seen done before


She rctnrnedup the cellar stairs into the scullc.
ry, took down pair ofbellows that hung IN,
ran up stairs MTG one of the bedrooms, and be.
I gan to blow at an empty CRATE. She then came
i down star5in great hurry, and in going down
let fall the bellows, which fell after her and
bruised the skin oil her heel; She went into the
sculIery, got the dripping pan, put some cups
and saucers &c upon il, and put them oytr tile
4 fire, In short time she took them off again.
4 mutterng, "TAcrc you'll do now" She then
caine lnto the sitting room, took up the poker,
and said, = will fight will fight Tile ser
want wrcsted i from her, when she ran into the
mont lobby and fell down, the servant took her
HuH, carried hsr INTO the stting-room, and shook
hert iu!ently n = short time she seemed to be
awaAing and was asked, "WhAt have you been
/ doing She answered, as at first, 'Wshing
tie lalics good night" During the whole OF
the time shv had her eyes quite closed and the
servant Srl (who Is youns) was SO alarmed, that
she llarel! not leave her but followed her from
thc iirSt. when the Young lady was thoroughly
awt!ted, shl began 10 be sick, and vomited pro,
ta5eN, ana was extremely unwell. She Went
% bed ebont the usual hour, and was awakened
With considerable difficulty the next morning At
Laser hour lAAn She Was wont TO rise.

mcetiug ef the scco,d chamber; a holding
Of the full diet. where the magnates attend,
l w13 not fortunate enough to sec. and am
left III spite OF all descriptions, a little in
doubt. as to the picture it would actually
present; magnificent it may hr. yet et,methinks,
Judging from what | did see, the splendor
has been somewhat exaggerated, that of the
guard noble undoubtedly is. They have
good but not remarkable horses. The hus-
sar dress Of scarlet and silver is rich and
dazzling. and as they ride down to mount
guard, 10 see them followed by trains OF or
dcrics mounted, and with led horses, altho'
the peiisscs of these ordcrles were old, and
rusty green, and the horses might havc been
turned ont in higher order; has an appear
ance somewhat imposing. But the young
men composing this corps differ in size, fig
ure and carriage, and scarce look soldiers
bv the side of the old Austrian cuirrassiers.
4 regiment of these last lay in garrison here
and some strong battalions OF infantry, con


ssting entirely OF men from the Italian prov


inces of the empire. So much for the hous-
es Of lords and commons at Pressburgh, and
for the chance oi free discussion in the king


dom Of Hungary"

Healths.--The origin Of health drinking
took it's rise from the time of the Danes be.
ing in England, when it was common with
them, whilst an Englshman was drinking,
to take that opportunity Of stabbing him.
To guard against this Danish tfeachery, the
English entered into combination TO be
mutual pledges of security 70 each other
whilst drinking. When, therefore, an Eng
lishman at that period drank to his friend,
his tacit language was-"Sir, ! am afraid
that some malicious Dane will stab me or
cut my throat whilst | am drinking beg
the favor of YOU to watch carefully that !
may drink safely


10 which his friend was supposed to an
swer, "Sr, will pledge you aud be your
safety" He then replied, Il am much O.
blged to YOU, sir.-your health. that you
may live till have done drinking, and save
me from his wicked Intentions UAiPsrsal


Mga-ine.

mont, coming 10 one Of the rivers where the
bridge had been swept away, and where the
torrent was still Of fearful depth, secured
the mail TO his body, plunged his horses IN,
and swan through. On being asked why
he yentured upon SO hazardous an expert
ment, he replied with a genuine yankee sang
t'od, ,-"why there is a fine if we don't de-
liver the mail in season, and / guess they
don't get their fifty dollars out OF me, and be
dGrn'a to them"

From The Montreal CourQnt, of Man IL.


On Thursday morning last, as the steam
boat Chambly was coming up from Quebec


with detachment Of the 71st Regiment on
board, when between Long Point and Point
aux Trembles, a soldier named John Spears.
who had been asleep on one Of the wings. fell
overheard; alarm was instantly given, the
vessel was stopped, and boat put off in
search of the lost man--but to no purpose.
The steamboat then pursued her way for
thisp place. The accident happened at about
two A, M. and about ten, before the detach-

full articles.article:
Chesapeake and Dtiaware Canak-It af-
foris us peculiar qualification to state that
the work Of the Chesapeake and Delaware
Canal is progressing equal to cur most SAN
gulne expectations Mcssrs. Raybold and
Clark have rendered their contract naviga-
bic as far as the village Of St. Georges, which
has been cut through the worst ground, at
distance Of about five miles. On Monday,
we are informed. several sloops entered the
lock on the Delaware, and passed up the
canal in handsome stVle, as far asst. Georges
where their arrival was greeted by the citi
zcns Of that place with acclamatons ef joy.
These contractors, ever since they first en-.
gagged this section Of the work, have been
unceasing in their eXcrtions to render il CON
pletc in their limited time:-they harc done
So: and the mastery manner in which they
have surmounted difficulties which, almost
every day, were presenting themselves %
one shape or another, is truly admirable.
The western section, under the management
Of MIR ID Xtcr, We are also iHformcd, pro
gresses rapidly; several miles Being now fin
ishtd. The middle section, ar deep CT,
as il is called, is also in a state of forward
ness, and we think viii soon be brought q
is proper depth. Tbe impcdincnts enths
part Of the canal are tmhing, when comndr.
ed with those Oh the marshes, where quit K


sands and soft mud Bottoms have abuan.,ld
] beyond expectation, All that is hero ~
quired, is sufficient ph,si force. 70 r.
move the dirt with expedition. Il i be-
lieved, by Judges, that the canal viii bc p a
condition 70 admit the passing pf boats, from
the Delaware 10 tic Chesapeake, hy the ial
Of 1928; some say earlier, but We believe tie
present condition d the work does not justly
shorter tme--tt viii then be finished in
rough state, and my probably require sis
o. nine months more, % give it a fihsdins
touch 50 that ay the fourth 81 July, N q


the canal vii! bc completed

situated aL tUt Hcdl vi AhS Jay N'' - >N'--
rnandng eminence, can garrison 600 troops.
The Twelve Apostles, directly at the foot
Of the Moro. would itself command the en-
trance into the harbour-and 1t, IN addi-
.ien to these, the forts at the Punta, opPo-
site, be taken into the account. It VIII be
seen that Havana has the means of making
most powerful resistance against any invaa-
er, should there be internal peace and mar
mony. .o
yr There are in and about Havana, 750o
troons all of whom have been sent from
Spain. They are well ted, clothed ana uls-
cinlincd. they receive l. dollars per month
for wages. from which are usually deducted
about three dollars for their uniform, &c
They have beet sent from Spain Tor various
causes, some because they are faithful, ana
some because they had fought tor the CON
stituton. The first year OF their arrival
they are usually subject to the fever, and no
small number fall thus sacrificed. Spain,
however, must have Spanish soldiers, as she
can never trust the islanders; and 1t feid-
nand has discontinued regiment, Cuba at
fords good place for tomb Its suppos-
cd that &C, 900 soldiers might be raised IN
the island, in case of union and emergency.
But so great is the apprehension OF the GO
vernment towards the natives, that durIass
the past winter, it was found necessary 10
send large body of troops from Havana to
Mantanzas, because they were commanded
by Cuban officers.


The troops parade every day, either IN the
Plaza de Armas or eatramdroS her com
mon dress is white coarse linen, with black
cloth cap and yellow tassels. Their tull UNI
form, however, is leather cap with tea
ther, blue cloth coat, and white trowsers, Ia
ced, white and plated buttons they are al
ways remarkably clean. Com W. OF the
United States Navy, told me that he never
saw finer troops, nor did he think It possible
to drill men more perfectly. some OF the
other officers found, did not concur entirely
with the Commodore, as to their ability to
withstand a charge of a British force Of G.
quail number; inasmuch as 10 mass, they
are not as stout men as the latter.


AS to the ability of a foreign power TO
take Havana, there is great difference OF
opinion. The troops which occupy It hay
ing been sent away from their own country
against their will. might, in case OF an in
surrection, either join with the rebels, or,
If a foreign power should come, might Gre
ate such discomfort, as to render the efforts
of their officers unavailing. II IN addition
to this, the distraction and jealousy oi the
natives be considered, it viii appear possl.
ble, that without much expense, either OF
treasure or blood, Havana might fall. The
Cabana being commanded by ali eminence
within distance, might possibly be taken,
and then the Moro must fall, as well as the
other fortresses The walls OF the city
would be no protection, as the houses oht-
aide would completely shelter the approach
OF besegers. BY cutting OFT the supplies
Of the city for provisions and water, lthe
work of an hour,) and driving the nhabit-


|, - +h. lie ~
must inevitably tolow--and to famine en-
ptulation The climate so fatal to toreig~
ers Of the north is no less 50 to Spaniard
from the mother country; and hence, in TIN
respect, there would be no advantage TO thu
latter. Should Havana fall, Cuba become
an easy prey. The English Gould probabl,
take it as easily as they did in 1162


At that time the English land forces tttet
out for the siege OF this place, were commltte
to the command of the Earl OF Albtmatlt
Their number was about 10000 The tlcH
was entrusted to Admiral Pocockc, an
consisted q. 19 ships of the line, is irlg@ta'
and 15Otransports. They moved in sight {
the Notifications on the 10th Of June, 17G.
Opposed TO this were IL the harbour, !
Spanish ships Of the line. post was sel2e
on the high ground already mentioned, a
though in consequence OF lightness of tl
earth. THIS was eT1tCleu Will lJlHlNC ilWNH
". The soldiers and sailors were oplige
to drag the cannon up the decivty on th
east Of the present Cabanas, and being e.
posed to the heat Of the burning sun, ulan
of them dropped down dead. The batterIt
were fianally opened. The garrison, IN 8
tempting 10 destroy them had been repulsc
with great slaughter.-bu the principal ba
tery took fire accidentally, ard thus the j
bour Of 1000 Of the besiegers was lost in
few hours Two thirds of the soldiers an
sailors had by this time become unfit for So
vice, yet the besiegers pressed on, and


mine having been sprung which threw dos
a part Of the works INTO the ditch left
breach, and the soldiers were ordered


storm the works.


The assault was commenced; four hu
dred Of the Spanish soldiers were cut


pieces, or lost i'll attempting TO leap from q


NIoro the rest received quarters on layi


down their arms. This occurred thirty da
after the commencement ct the siege. L


British commandant speedily remount


the runs of the fort to the number OF SIX


pieces; but willing to spare the city, a


prevent unnecessary bloodshed, sentl A


Of truce to the governor to surrender. /


s,pan.art refused The next morning aft
the batteries we're opened with such eff,
against town and forts, that flags OF tru


appeared in every part OF the city at abe


twelve O'clock A deputy was sent to I


British camD to settle the terms of catlitu

SOCIETY," OF FRIENDS.
full articles.article:
Az might have been expected from the
high banded measures that have been pur-
sued w those termed "intolerants" among
the Friends, i large body of the Representa-
tives ,ull ministers at the late yearly meet
ine IN this place, met at the meeting house
in Green street, and unanimously resolved to
come OUT from under the jurisdiction and au-
tbority Of the chief elders and rulers in this
city, and be no longer subject to their pow
cr and dictation 'fhey have prepared an
Address to the members composing the va
rinus quarterly meetings, stating their grew
ances aud intentions, md are taking meas
nreG ngenaratory to the establishment OF
Yearly NJ ting, more tolerant in its prin-
cioles, aud better adapted for securing their
rights and privileges In this movement are
4 number of ministers and mcmbers OF the
first stan1ing in the soeiety. Among the
ministers awe Abraham Lower, Edward
Hicks, and I4hn Comly, author Of the spell
ing-boak, and Eng,ish grammar, now n SUCH
general uSr in thc,t parts.


II is expected that most of the Qnarer'y
Meetings will unite in the measure which
has been taken, and that the head Elders
Ard their partiznns in this place. will he
left quite in the minority. Situated as th3
Society has been FIR some time past, wilat
has been done seems the oni4 gr4per course
that could be takcn for securing peace and
tranquility among both the parties.
